title: ID - Heading from 1930 German textbook
content:
Hi,

I cant get a exact match on this one.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016160527im_/http:/typophile.com/files/font_id1_5921.png)

Anybody know?

Thanks

 [‹ Can you identify this font please?](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016160527/http:/typophile.com/node/38035 "Go to previous forum topic") [Page Six typeface (title) ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016160527/http:/typophile.com/node/38032 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Andy B

comments.content:
Looks like Bookman. The closest digital versions I could find are [Bookman Headline](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016160527/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/bitstream/bookman_headline/?sample_text=ationale%20F&sample_size=36) and [Bookman Old Style.](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016160527/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/monotype/bookman_old_style/?sample_text=ationale%20F&sample_size=36)

- Lex

I originally read your title as “Heading from 1930s German textbook”. If it’s from 1930, the font is probably Antique Old Style, the precursor to Bookman.

- Lex
Thanks Lex. It does indeed look like Antique No. 7 old style. I feel a bit silly now, especially as I have a reprint of a Miller & Richard specimen book sitting on my desk.
